articles.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: White House Debates How Far to Go on Face Mask Guidelines
articles.description: The coordinator of the coronavirus response emphasized that social distancing was still the most important step people could take. Critical medicines are running low, and nearly 10 million Americans have lost their jobs.

articles.title: Trump Sees Hope for Boosting Global Oil Prices and Helping U.S. Firms
articles.description: The president’s optimism for a deal between Saudi Arabia and Russia to reduce production and a Saudi call for talks send crude prices skyrocketing, but Moscow showed little enthusiasm.

articles.title: A Widening Toll on Jobs: ‘This Thing Is Going to Come for Us All’
articles.description: After the initial impact of shutdowns on a few industries, the coronavirus pandemic is leaving a much broader swath of unemployment.

articles.title: N.Y.C. Death Toll Tops 1,500 as Cuomo Warns on Ventilators
articles.description: The governor said the state was using the machines for coronavirus patients at a rate that would exhaust its stockpile in just six days.

articles.title: Touting Virus Cure, ‘Simple Country Doctor’ Becomes a Right-Wing Star
articles.description: How Dr. Vladimir Zelenko’s claims for his coronavirus treatment spread from a New York village all the way to President Trump.

articles.title: Trump’s Company Seeks to Ease Financial Crunch as Coronavirus Takes Toll
articles.description: As companies nationwide look for relief, the Trump Organization has talked with Deutsche Bank and a Florida county about delaying payments on some loans and other obligations.

articles.title: The 1,000-Bed Comfort Was Supposed to Aid New York. It Has 20 Patients.
articles.description: “It’s a joke,” said a top hospital executive, whose facilities are packed with coronavirus patients.

articles.title: Ex-Wife Sick. Daughter Sick. 3 Friends Dead. Everyone Knows Someone.
articles.description: The growing number of coronavirus cases and deaths have touched family and social circles across New York City, making the invisible threat seem far more real.

articles.title: One Hospital’s Last Resort to Protect Doctors: Yankee Rain Ponchos
articles.description: The hospital, in the Bronx, said the ponchos were intended as a gift to weary workers, but several staffers said they were told to use them as protective equipment.

articles.title: Where America Didn’t Stay Home Even as the Virus Spread
articles.description: People in Florida and elsewhere continued to travel widely last week, potentially exposing more people to the coronavirus, phone data shows.

articles.title: Essential Drug Supplies for Virus Patients Are Running Low
articles.description: Medicines to alleviate breathing difficulty, relieve pain and sedate coronavirus patients are in very high demand, depleting stock around the country.

articles.title: ‘I’m Scared’: Wisconsin Election Puts Poll Workers at Risk of Virus
articles.description: The state plans to hold its elections on Tuesday, thrusting thousands of clerks and poll workers, many of them older or with health conditions, onto the pandemic’s front lines.

articles.title: C.I.A. Hunts for Authentic Virus Totals in China, Dismissing Government Tallies
articles.description: Intelligence officials have told the White House for weeks that China has vastly understated the spread of the coronavirus and the damage the pandemic has done.

articles.title: U.N. Security Council ‘Missing In Action’ in Coronavirus Fight
articles.description: The leader of the U.N. has called the pandemic the biggest international threat in the 75-year history of the organization, but its most powerful body has yet to take action.

articles.title: From Afar, Congress Moves to Oversee Trump Coronavirus Response
articles.description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced she would move to form a special committee to scrutinize the Trump administration’s response, including how more than $2 trillion in federal relief money is being spent.

articles.title: Kushner Puts Himself in Middle of White House’s Chaotic Coronavirus Response
articles.description: President Trump’s son-in-law has become a central player in the administration’s effort to curb the pandemic. But critics say he is part of the problem.

articles.title: How Jerome Powell’s Unconventional Career Path Prepared Him for This Crisis
articles.description: His winding career path now seems to be a strength, not a weakness.

articles.title: ‘It’s Just So Devastating’: For Crestfallen Gymnasts, an Olympic Dream Deferred
articles.description: Female gymnasts often compete at younger ages than their Olympic peers and have a far more concentrated opportunity at the top. Into that intense world dropped the coronavirus pandemic.

articles.title: Coronavirus, President Trump, Democratic Party: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
articles.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

articles.title: Delicious Vinyl
articles.description: We examine when culture from our past — like the 20-year-old comedy “High Fidelity” — gets reborn … as “High Fidelity.”

articles.title: When Silly Start-Ups Falter, We All Lose
articles.description: The pandemic is devastating start-ups. This matters in ways we can’t always see.

articles.title: The President vs. the Governors
articles.description: And how should Joe Biden campaign amid the coronavirus?

articles.title: Wearing Masks Must Be a National Policy
articles.description: Even homemade face coverings provide some protection, especially when many people who have the coronavirus show no symptoms.

articles.title: What if I Have to Decide Who Gets a Ventilator?
articles.description: Thinking about the choices I could have to make as I treat patients with the coronavirus breaks my heart.

articles.title: Jared Kushner Is Going to Get Us All Killed
articles.description: Trump’s son-in-law has no business running the coronavirus response.

articles.title: Mental Health in the Age of the Coronavirus
articles.description: The struggle between fear and comfort.

articles.title: The Covid-19 Slump Has Arrived
articles.description: But we’re already botching the response.

articles.title: There’s Only One Thing Stopping Trump From Deporting Health Care Workers
articles.description: If the Supreme Court affirms the administration’s termination of DACA, thousands of vital health care workers could be deported.

articles.title: Coronavirus Advice: Wear a Mask. Here’s How.
articles.description: Two psychiatrists urge the public to overcome any hesitation, and a surgeon gives advice on how to wear a mask. Other readers offer a D.I.Y. tip and a historical note.

articles.title: Why Are So Many More Men Dying from Coronavirus?
articles.description: The disproportionate toll this virus is taking on males isn’t an anomaly. When it comes to survival, men are the weaker sex.

articles.title: The Only Way You Can See Milan Is to Fly Through It
articles.description: Here’s what it’s like in a coronavirus red zone.

articles.title: Detroit Is Mourning
articles.description: With a spike in coronavirus cases, many of us are left wondering why.

articles.title: The Surprising Intimacy of the Live-Streamed Funeral
articles.description: Because of the coronavirus, memorial services are moving online, where mourners find that collective grief is still possible.

articles.title: My Partner Works in an Amazon Warehouse. I’m Worried — and Proud.
articles.description: Disrobing in the hallway, dodging hugs and fretting over our children’s safety. This is our family’s new normal.

articles.title: A.A. Saved My Life. Can It Work Online?
articles.description: Holding hands and bearing witness in a musty basement got me through. The virtual world is different.

articles.title: They All Retired Before They Hit 40. Then This Happened.
articles.description: The stock market wasn’t going to create wealth forever. So what about the FIRE movement?

articles.title: Labor Fight Collides With the Pandemic at Trader Joe’s
articles.description: The chain has aggressively opposed unionization efforts among its employees, who have been critical of its response to the coronavirus.

articles.title: Man Pleads Guilty to Plotting to Attack White House With Anti-Tank Missile
articles.description: Hasher Jallal Taheb, 23, also targeted the Statue of Liberty, the Washington Monument, the Lincoln Memorial and a synagogue, prosecutors said.

articles.title: Hobby Lobby Defies Stay-at-Home Orders by Reopening Some Stores
articles.description: Authorities in two states sent cease-and-desist letters to the craft store chain.

articles.title: Ken Shimura, Comedian Whose Sketches Delighted Japan, Dies at 70
articles.description: His slapstick humor, physical comedy and naïve persona made him a household name in the country for decades.

articles.title: As Tekashi69 Is Released, Inmates Fearing Coronavirus Ask, ‘Why Not Me?’
articles.description: The rapper will serve the final four months of his two-year term in home confinement. High-profile inmates like Bill Cosby and R. Kelly are arguing for home confinement too, so far without success.

articles.title: Under Modi, India’s Press Is Not So Free Anymore
articles.description: India’s government has pressured advertisers and even shut down channels to shape the information that 1.3 billion Indians receive. It’s part of a wider assault on dissent.

articles.title: How Will Joe Biden Find His Joe Biden?
articles.description: Joe Biden and his associates are consulting allies, Eric Holder and Barack Obama as he weighs his options — including a woman of color — for the Democratic candidate for vice president.

articles.title: DeVos Weighs Waiving Special Education. Parents Are Worried.
articles.description: The $2 trillion coronavirus law grants the education secretary the power to waive special education rules as school districts struggle to teach all their students online.

articles.title: No Live Sports on TV? Consumers Want a Refund
articles.description: Some providers break out sports fees on bills. With seasons on pause because of the coronavirus, it’s another reminder to customers of what they’re paying for but not getting.

articles.title: Don’t Need That $1,200 Stimulus Check? Here Are Places to Donate It.
articles.description: The federal government approved a $2 trillion stimulus package, which includes direct payments to millions of Americans to help get through the coronavirus outbreak. If you don’t need the money, here are some ideas to help you give it to someone in need.

articles.title: Wondering About Social Distancing?
articles.description: Answers to your most common questions about the best practices for stemming the tide of the coronavirus pandemic.

articles.title: We Get, and Give, Lots of Bad Advice. Here’s How to Stop.
articles.description: One of the most effective ways to get better advice is to give it.

articles.title: How to Work From Home Now That Your Boss Doesn’t Want You Coming In
articles.description: If your company is making you work from home during the coronavirus outbreak, here’s what you need to make that transition work.

articles.title: 9 Delightful Articles to Help You Get Through This Week
articles.description: We’re all just trying to do our best now. These articles might help a little.

articles.title: Peter Gatien, the ’90s ‘Club King,’ Wants His Final Say
articles.description: The Limelight and Tunnel are long gone. But the story of their vilified owner is still being written.

articles.title: Pokémon, Stay
articles.description: For almost four years, I’ve been playing a game that brings players out into the world. What happens when the world goes away?

articles.title: A Mexican Novel Conjures a Violent World Tinged With Beauty
articles.description: “Hurricane Season,” by Fernanda Melchor, imagines Mexico’s scourge of violence against women in language that is fierce, profane and marvelously inventive.

articles.title: Coronavirus Coping: Novak Djokovic Is Playing Tennis With Frying Pans
articles.description: Promotion and relegation concerns abound as soccer and rugby leagues consider canceling. In better news, Enes Kanter is cooking up a storm.

articles.title: A Stay-at-Home Whiskey Project: The Infinity Bottle
articles.description: Enthusiasts around the world post their personal blends of various whiskeys to social media under the hashtag “infinitybottle.”

articles.title: The Experience of Getting Tested for Coronavirus
articles.description: Here are some of the experiences and bits of advice from those who have been able to get tested.

articles.title: ‘What Are the Symptoms?’ ‘Is There a Cure?’ and Other Coronavirus Questions
articles.description: Here’s what to do if you feel sick and are worried it may be the coronavirus.

articles.title: Restrictions Are Slowing Coronavirus Infections, New Data Suggest
articles.description: A database of daily fever readings shows that the numbers declined as people disappeared indoors.

articles.title: This Fireball Ignored the Solar System’s One-Way Signs
articles.description: A meteoroid that grazed the night sky over Australia in 2017 took a very unusual path away from Earth.
